metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C Strings
Strings
Strings are used for storing text/characters.
For example, "Hello World" is a string of characters.
content.html: For example, "Hello World" is a string of characters.

content.text: Unlike many other programming languages, C does not have a String type to easily create string variables. Instead, you must use the char type and create an array of characters to make a string in C:
content.html: Unlike many other programming languages, C does not have a String type to easily create string variables. Instead, you must use the char type and create an array of characters to make a string in C:

content.code_html: char greetings[] = "Hello World!";

content.text: Note that you have to use double quotes ( "" ).
content.html: Note that you have to use double quotes ("").

content.text: To output the string, you can use the printf() function together with the format specifier %s to tell C that we are now working with strings:
content.html: To output the string, you can use the printf() function together with the format specifier %s to tell C that we are now working with strings:

content.code_html:
char greetings[] = "Hello World!";
printf("%s", greetings);

content.text: Access Strings
Since strings are actually arrays in C, you can access a string by referring to its index number inside square brackets [] .
content.html: Since strings are actually arrays in C, you can access a string by referring to its index number inside square brackets [].

content.text: This example prints the first character (0) in greetings :

content.code_html:
char greetings[] = "Hello World!";
printf("%c", greetings[0]);

content.text: Note that we have to use the %c format specifier to print a single character .
content.html: Note that we have to use the %c format specifier to print a single character.

content.text: Modify Strings
To change the value of a specific character in a string, refer to the index number, and use single quotes :
content.html: To change the value of a specific character in a string, refer to the index number, and use single quotes:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Outputs Jello World! instead of Hello 
  World!

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Outputs Jello World! instead of Hello 
  World!

content.code_html:
char greetings[] = "Hello World!";
greetings[0] = 'J';
printf("%s", greetings);
// Outputs Jello World! instead of Hello World!

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Outputs Jello World! instead of Hello 
  World!

content.text: Loop Through a String
You can also loop through the characters of a string, using a for loop:
content.html: You can also loop through the characters of a string, using a for loop:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
char carName[] = "Volvo";int i;for (i = 0; i < 5; ++i) {  
  printf("%c\n", carName[i]);}

content.code:
char carName[] = "Volvo";int i;for (i = 0; i < 5; ++i) {
printf("%c\n", carName[i]);}

syntax_highlighting.text:
char carName[] = "Volvo";int i;for (i = 0; i < 5; ++i) {  
  printf("%c\n", carName[i]);}

content.code_html:
char carName[] = "Volvo";
int i;

for (i = 0; i < 5; ++i) {
  printf("%c\n", carName[i]);
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
char carName[] = "Volvo";int i;for (i = 0; i < 5; ++i) {  
  printf("%c\n", carName[i]);}

content.text: And like we specified in the arrays chapter, you can also use the sizeof formula (instead of manually write the size of the array in the loop condition (i < 5) ) to make the loop more sustainable:
content.html: And like we specified in the arrays chapter, you can also use the sizeof formula (instead of manually write the size of the array in the loop condition (i < 5)) to make the loop more sustainable:

content.code_html:
char carName[] = "Volvo";
int length = sizeof(carName) / sizeof(carName[0]);
int i;

for (i = 0; i < length; ++i) {
  printf("%c\n", carName[i]);
}

content.text: Another Way Of Creating Strings
In the examples above, we used a "string literal" to create a string variable. This is the easiest way to create a string in C.
content.html: In the examples above, we used a "string literal" to create a string variable. This is the easiest way to create a string in C.

content.text: You should also note that you can create a string with a set of characters. This example will produce the same result as the example in the beginning of this page:
content.html: You should also note that you can create a string with a set of characters. This example will produce the same result as the example in the beginning of this page:

content.code_html:
char greetings[] = {'H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', ' ', 'W', 'o', 'r', 'l', 'd', '!', '\0'};
printf("%s", greetings);

content.text: Why do we include the \0 character at the end? This is known as the "null terminating character", and must be included when creating strings using this method. It tells C that this is the end of the string.
content.html: Why do we include the \0 character at the end? This is known as the "null terminating character", and must be included when creating strings using this method. It tells C that this is the end of the string.

content.text: Differences
The difference between the two ways of creating strings, is that the first method is easier to write, and you do not have to include the \0 character, as C will do it for you.
content.html: The difference between the two ways of creating strings, is that the first method is easier to write, and you do not have to include the \0 character, as C will do it for you.

content.text: You should note that the size of both arrays is the same: They both have 13 characters (space also counts as a character by the way), including the \0 character:
content.html: You should note that the size of both arrays is the same: They both have 13 characters (space also counts as a character by the way), including the \0 character:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
char greetings[] = {'H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', ' ', 'W', 'o', 'r', 'l', 'd', 
  '!', '\0'};char greetings2[] = "Hello World!";printf("%lu\n", 
  sizeof(greetings));   // Outputs 13printf("%lu\n", 
  sizeof(greetings2));  // Outputs 13

content.code:
char greetings[] = {'H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', ' ', 'W', 'o', 'r', 'l', 'd',
'!', '\0'};char greetings2[] = "Hello World!";printf("%lu\n",
sizeof(greetings));   // Outputs 13printf("%lu\n",
sizeof(greetings2));  // Outputs 13

syntax_highlighting.text:
char greetings[] = {'H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', ' ', 'W', 'o', 'r', 'l', 'd', 
 '!', '\0'};char greetings2[] = "Hello World!";printf("%lu\n", 
  sizeof(greetings));   // Outputs 13printf("%lu\n", 
  sizeof(greetings2));  // Outputs 13

content.code_html:
char greetings[] = {'H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', ' ', 'W', 'o', 'r', 'l', 'd', '!', '\0'};
char greetings2[] = "Hello World!";

printf("%lu\n", sizeof(greetings));   // Outputs 13
printf("%lu\n", sizeof(greetings2));  // Outputs 13

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
char greetings[] = {'H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', ' ', 'W', 'o', 'r', 'l', 'd', 
  '!', '\0'};char greetings2[] = "Hello World!";printf("%lu\n", 
  sizeof(greetings));   // Outputs 13printf("%lu\n", 
  sizeof(greetings2));  // Outputs 13

content.text: Real-Life Example
Use strings to create a simple welcome message:
content.html: Use strings to create a simple welcome message:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
char message[] = "Good to see you,";char fname[] = "John";printf("%s 
  %s!", message, fname);

content.code:
char message[] = "Good to see you,";char fname[] = "John";printf("%s
%s!", message, fname);

syntax_highlighting.text:
char message[] = "Good to see you,";char fname[] = "John";printf("%s 
  %s!", message, fname);

content.code_html:
char message[] = "Good to see you,";
char fname[] = "John";

printf("%s %s!", message, fname);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
char message[] = "Good to see you,";char fname[] = "John";printf("%s 
  %s!", message, fname);

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is the correct way to declare a string in C with the text 'Hello World'?
content.html: What is the correct way to declare a string in C with the text 'Hello World'?
